Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2014 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Alexander Volfovsky is "Design, Testing, and Estimation for Social Networks." The host institution for the fellowship is Harvard University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Edoardo Airoldi.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The work supported by this project has contributed to statistical inference in several major and distinct ways. 


First, it has provided a theoretical justification for employing computationally simple models while analyzing social network formation. A foundational assumption in many network problems is that individuals in a network are infinitely exchangeable---that is, they are sampled from an infinite population and the order in which the individuals in a network are observed is not relevant to statistical inference. While the second half of the assumption appears reasonable, the assumption of an infinite population appears problematic. However, not making this assumption makes the analysis computationally intractable. As part of this project we demonstrated that violations of this assumption likely do not corrupt statistical inference, thus justifying the standard computationally tractable models.


Second, the results of this project provide an approach for evaluating the effects of treatments that are applied to different social networks. Modern problems in the health and social sciences frequently involve individuals who are connected by different network ties. Not accounting for such connections in the analysis of experimental or observational data can lead to biased estimated and poor quantification of uncertainty about causal quantities. This project developed the tools necessary for understanding how a particular treatment (such as a mailer or a social media post) influences individual behavior when network effects (such as the influence of friends) are present. 


A third contribution of this project was to the development of novel tools necessary for assessing the uncertainty in the analysis of experiments due to missing data. Most data collection efforts are imperfect which leads to certain quantities being unobserved. Ignoring such missingness patterns can lead to poor inference but imputing the values in an unprincipled ways can introduce new and different issues. In this project we propose a principled way for performing multiple imputations---a technique that generates several possible values for each missing value which allows for better understanding the effects of missing data on quantities of interest. 


Beyond statistical methodology and theory, the work this project funded will help inform the development and analysis of experiments in the social and health sciences. Properly accounting for missingness, network effects and violations of foundational assumptions will lead to more principled and proper inference.
